You canвЂ™t smoke here.

Not even inside. The calm voice belongs to the man sitting across from him English, about eighty years old, in a soft beige jacket a trousers, and eyeglasses with imposing black frames, behi which nest watery, light blue eyes, laden with melancholy cunning. WeвЂ™re talking about Fred Ballinger. ThereвЂ™s a small table between them. An open newspaper i front of Fred. He is calm, placid, serene, but a vague disenchantment hovers in his eyes. In what we realize is habitual gesture, he unwraps a candy and pops it in his mouth. HeвЂ™s clearly a regular consumer of such candies.
Pardon me, Mr. Ballinger, or may I call you Maestro? Fred Ballinger shrugs his shoulders. It really doesnвЂ™t to him. FIFTY-YEAR OLD (CONTвЂ™D) And may I ask how your holiday is going?
Very well, thank you.
Have you been coming here long?
For more than twenty years. I used to come with my wife. Then I kept coming on my own, I have many friends here.
Why Switzerland, Maestro?
It's close to Italy. And I directed the Venice orchestra for twenty- four years. After London and New York, of course.
But of course, how silly of me! This must also be a very good place to relax.
ItвЂ™s only a place to relax. The fifty-year old smiles. Fred doesnвЂ™t.
Are you still directing or composing, Maestro?
No, IвЂ™m retired.
It goes without saying, of course, that I, like everyone else, ama great admirer of yours.
Thank you. The fifty-year old smiles.
Maestro, as I indicated to you in my letter, I work for the Ceremonies and Events Office at Buckingham Palace. Fred stirs slightly when he hears this.
You work for the Queen?
Well, in a sense, yes!
Good. Monarchies are always so endearing.
(surprised) If I may, Maestro, why exactly do you find the monarchy endearing?
Because itвЂ™s so vulnerable. Eliminate just one person and all of a sudden the whole world changes. Like in a marriage.
Her Majesty the Queen would be honored to confer a knighthood upon you this coming June, Maestro. A little smile darts across Fred's face.

Do you know what Satie said when he was offered the Legion of Honor? вЂњItвЂ™s not enough simply to refuse it, you also have to not deserve it.вЂќ But I am not Satie. And you must excuse me, I have the most dreadful habit of quoting other people.
Her Majesty will be delighted to learn you have accepted.
Her Majesty has never been delighted about anything. Embarrassed, the QueenвЂ™s emissary skates over FredвЂ™s

What is more, your investiture just happens to coincide with the birthday of His Royal Highness The Prince Philip, and the Queen would very much like to give hima concert with the London Philharmonic Orchestra at the New Wimbledon Theatre, to which the Prince is deeply attached, for reasons unknown to me. Her Majesty would be delight-- honored if you would agree to conduct, your own compositions of course.
I havenвЂ™t conducted for a long time.
(smiles) IвЂ™m sure you haven't forgotten how itвЂ™s done. Fred Ballinger ponders this.
No, I havenвЂ™t forgotten how itвЂ™s done. The QueenвЂ™s emissaryвЂ™s smiles radiantly.
Prince Philip and Her Majesty will be simply ecstatic to hear you conduct your famous вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ In a remarkably calm, resigned voice, Fred says:
Ah, but I will not conduct any of my вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ
Why not?
Personal reasons.
The great soprano Sumi Jo has agreed to sing.
Sumi Jo won't do.
Well then, tell me which soprano would do, and you shall have her.

No one will do. Fred BallingerвЂ™s refusal seems irrevocable. He goes bac reading the paper, all the flattery already behind him. T emissary is devastated. He lowers his head. Silence. Only a slight noise. The camera moves to discove what it is. Fred is rubbing the plastic-coated candy wrap between his fingers at regular intervals. Without a doubt the quick, alternating tempo creates a distinct musical rhythm. The QueenвЂ™s emissary puts a cigarette between his lips about to light it when he remembers that smoking is not permitted. He stammers out one last, lame attempt.
If I may, Maestro, the Queen might take your refusal rather poorly, sheвЂ™s not used to being told no. Fred Ballinger, who is reading the paper, interrupts ex abrupto rubbing the candy wrapper.
IвЂ™m sure she will come to terms with it. There are far more important things in life than my Simple Songs. The emissary is disconsolate.

Well then, I shall relay our conversation to the Queen. Good day, Maestro. The emissary takes his leave. His two assistants follow h When they get up, we see that there is a man sitting behi them, who looks as if he has overheard the whole conversation. His name is Jimmy Tree. HeвЂ™s thirty-four years old, Californian, drop dead handsome, a Hollywood star. Though itвЂ™s still early, heвЂ™s eating a steak and French frie Hiding behind sunglasses and a few days' razor stubble, wearing an unflattering baseball cap and sloppy clothes, looks undone. The three Englishmen are circumnavigating the pool on the way out of the garden, when someone suddenly catches the emissaryвЂ™s attention. This someone is floating in the pool: a man about fifty, his face above water. A puffy, South American face, hair a surreal yellow, full lips, tired features, dark, intelligent eyes, and furrows far too deep for a man his He stares blankly into space. The emissary gazes at the South American and whispers to of his assistants. FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY (CONTвЂ™D) Do you see that man? Could it really be him? His two assistants turn to look at the man in the pool, a recognize him immediately. They get all excited.
Why yes, it is!

Good god, it really is him. The three Englishmen keep walking, but they canвЂ™t keep glancing furtively at the South American who, with the he of a woman in her forties and three lifeguards, whom he l on like a dead weight, is getting out of the pool. He struggles up the low stairs, which to him seem insurmountable. As he slowly emerges from the water, we see how extraordinarily obese he is, and how much trouble he has walking. Panting, this cumbersome yet charismatic creatur settles himself at the edge of the pool. His arms are swarming with tattoos: faces of famous heroes from famous revolutions. The lifeguards withdraw. The forty-year-old woman with a kindly, patient face is h companion, apparently. She sits next to him and lovingly his hair with a towel, caring for this immense whale. FADE OUT.

Guitar notes - irregular, sporadic, imploded, muffled sou that seem to come from the deepest depths of the sea or y own conscience - surface now and then during the scene. What we see next is like a vision. A breathtakingly beautiful vision: high water in a desert Saint MarkвЂ™s Square. That vast space, with its unforget porticos and palaces, is now a square lake, water lapping the columns. A narrow, raised walkway intersects the Square. But there no one on it, at least not right now. Then, in the dead of night in this most mysterious city, Ballinger appears at the far end of the long walkway. Lik all old people, he looks vulnerable as he shuffles along, taking tiny, trying steps. Fred looks up and espies a statuesque female figure comin toward him from the other end of the walkway. They move toward each other, the only human beings in this surreal, submerged Venice. TheyвЂ™re closer now, theyвЂ™re about t With ill-concealed amazement, Fred fixes his eyes on the woman: sheвЂ™s 6/1". An impossible beauty, with black hair and eyes so green seem fake, wearing a one-piece bathing suit and a sash th says MISS UNIVERSE. SheвЂ™s even closer now, approaching him with the solemn, inhuman gait of a top model in a big-time fashion show. They're about to meet. But the walkway is only three feet wide, so they both move aside to let the other pass witho falling in the water. ItвЂ™s inevitable that they touch. Universe's plentiful decolletГ© brushes against FredвЂ™s chest. He gazes up at her from below, as if he were beholding a benign tragedy. Like all beauty queens, she stares coldly into space, not even noticing her perfect body's fleeting contact with Fr Having avoided a mishap, they each proceed on their way. beauty queen sways off into the full moon, surrounded by expanse of water, like in some debatable Dolce & Gabbana dream. Fred shuffles along the walkway. HeвЂ™s afraid now, and w good reason: the water is rising quickly, flooding the walkway and swirling around his feet, his ankles, his kne Fred tries to hurry, but heвЂ™s old and the water tugs at legs. He turns and cries out in a suffocated voice, as if begging Miss Universe for help.

Melanie, Melanie! But Miss Universe is no longer there, itвЂ™s as if she evaporated. Fred keeps going, but not for much longer. The water is u his chest now, his neck, his chin, heвЂ™s panicked, a sti guitar note sounds, when, luckily...

The guitar notes flow now, crisp and real. Fred takes tiny steps toward them, the underwater pool li providing a shadowy glow. As he shuffles across the deserted lawn, the OPENING CRED start to roll, and a voice joins in with the guitar, itвЂ coming from the little group of people. The song is вЂњOnward,вЂќ a magnificent, somber, America ballad. Fred instinctively heads toward the music. Fred hovers near the edge of the gathering, where Mark Kozelek, guitar in his lap, is singing вЂњOnward.вЂќ Thre a twenty-year-old kid, and Jimmy Tree are there as well. little group, all mellow and relaxed, listens contentedly the great American folksinger. The OPENING CREDITS continue to roll as Fred Ballinger, standing slightly apart, listens to the beautiful ballad. Mark Kozelek notices him and is unable to conceal his emo at having such a distinguished spectator. Mark gives a reverential little bow with his head and the during an instrumental break, says to Fred.

Maestro. Fred smiles slightly. The OPENING CREDITS are over. Jimmy Tree is stretched out on the grass, eyes closed. He opens his eyes and sees Fred. They nod hello to each othe then Jimmy gestures aimiably to him to join him. Fred goe over and sits near Jimmy, perching on the edge of a chais lounge. Jimmy offers him a mug.
I slipped a bit of gin and tonic into the herbal tea. Interested, Mr. Ballinger?

No, thanks. I'd prefer a bit of herbal tea slipped into a gin and tonic. They both smile. Fred takes out a cloth handkerchief, quickly blows his no expertly folds his handkerchief and, in a habitual gestur has clearly done a million times, quickly wipes his nose times, then puts his handkerchief back in his jacket pock Jimmy Tree, an irresistible smile on his face, has observ FredвЂ™s handkerchief routine with utmost attention.
I was thinking today that you and I have the same problem.
Is that so.
We've been misunderstood our whole lives because we allowed ourselves to give in - just once - toa little levity.
Perhaps. Because levity is an irresistible temptation.

IвЂ™ve worked with all the great European and American directors, but IвЂ™1l be remembered forever for Mister Q, for a fucking robot. I had to wear a suit of armor that weighed two hundred pounds, you couldnвЂ™t even see my face. But every five minutes someone has to come up and remind me that I did Mister Q, the same way they remind you that you did those вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ And they forget that you also composed вЂњThe Black Prism,вЂќ вЂњThe Life of Hadrian,вЂќ and all the rest. Fred Ballinger smiles and so does Jimmy. TheyвЂ™re accomp now.
Because levity is also a perversion. What are you doing in Europe?
IвЂ™m doing a new film, in Germany, starting in a month. IвЂ™m developing the role.
Is it a lighthearted role?
That depends on your point of view.
Is it coming along well?
We'll see. Mark Kozelek breathes the last note of вЂњOnward.вЂќ The group claps languidly. Fred doesnвЂ™t join in. Then, stru to get up, he takes his leave of Jimmy.
ItвЂ™s late for me.  10.
Not for me. Fred smiles. Jimmy salutes him playfully, two fingers to temple. Fred moves off with the uncertain gait of an old man. Jim drinks and observes Fred's slow walk.

Fred Ballinger stands immobile in the lobby, across from reception desk. HeвЂ™s waiting for the elevator. A young night doorman stares blankly at a small, silent T A very petite, dignified-looking woman, who looks older t her sixty years, rings the doorbell. The doorman, without taking his eyes off the TV, presses a button and buzzes h in. The woman enters and sits on a bench. Melancholy and resigned, she stares into space. Fred Ballinger, still waiting for the elevator, has watched all this, his face expressionless. Finally, the elevator. An old contraption with a metal gr Fred steps inside. The elevator ascends. We see his silhouette rising.

It stops at his floor. A chubby, unattractive young woman about twenty, is waiting to take the elevator down. Her f is pocked here and there with pimples, an adolescent peculiarity that clashes with her sharp, aggressive look. can safely assume that sheвЂ™s a hooker, but a hooker sui generis. Fred forgets to look at her, and she pays no attention to him. Alone, Fred Ballinger makes his way down the hallway, tak tiny, slow steps. Next to every door are pairs of hiking boots, neatly arranged, which the guests have put out to aired. In the silence of the night, an old man in an electric wheelchair overtakes Fred and vanishes around a corner. The sound of a violin comes from one of the rooms, stoppi Fred in his tracks. He turns, searching for the source. I starts up again, from the beginning: only two notes, play poorly. SomeoneвЂ™s obviously practicing, one of those re tedious exercises. Fred takes a step in the direction of the sound, but it s again.  11. He is about to keep walking when he encounters his reflec in a mirror. He touches a sunspot on his temple, which he notices for the first time there in the mirror. 5. INT. MICK BOYLEвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT Those same violin notes start up again, but extra-diegeti now, and perfectly executed. They give life to a soft, melancholic music. We're in a room where confusion reigns: papers and notes spread all over the place, laptop computers left open and forgotten. Five kids - four guys and a girl - all under thirty, are sleeping, curled up in armchairs scattered he and there, and on the bed. They are sleeping the sleep of just. Fred Ballinger and another elderly man are standing in th room, he too about eighty years old, still attractive, hi hair a little long, his bright, sparkling eyes omnivorous full of life. His name is Mick Boyle. The two old men silently observe the sleeping kids. The violin vanishes. After a while.
Did you take a piss today?
Twice. Four drops. You?
Same. More or less.
More or less?
Less.
Look how beautiful they are.
Beautiful, yes.
If you only knew how moving it is to see them working on the screenplay. TheyвЂ™re so passionate.
They've caught your passion.
And have you lost yours?  12. Fred just shrugs. Mick, with what is clearly a habitual gesture, smooths hi hair across his forehead with the palm of his hand, and t changes the subject.
See those two? He points to the girl and one of the guys, who are sleepi on opposite sides of the room.
Of course I see them.
They're falling in love, but they don't know it yet. The girl, her eyes still closed, gives a smile that no on sees. Because sheвЂ™s not asleep.
How do you know?
(xreflects)I know because I know everything there is to know about love.
Then you'll have to give me lessons one of these days.
It's late now. Have you heard the latest? Joyce Owens, Miss Universe, is coming to stay. Apparently one of her prizes is a free week in our hotel.
Yeah, I heard. But it seems more like a punishment than a prize to me.
Which is just how it should be. Some forms of beauty have to be punished, to make life bearable for the rest of us.
HowвЂ™s the screenplay coming along?
ItвЂ™s going to be my masterpiece. My testament. (MORE )
And Brenda is going to make an unforgettable leading lady. We hit on the title today: вЂњLifeвЂ™s Last Day.вЂќ What do you think?
(reflects) ItвЂ™s good. IвЂ™m going to bed. Fred heads out while in the background Mick shakes one of kids.

Come on, guys, wake up, it's time to go back to your hotel. 6. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT A beautiful woman, about forty, sleeps soundly in the bed Her name is Lena. A sweeping shot of the room. We see the night stand, with framed photograph from ten years ago, of Fred being hugge a woman his age. They smile happily in the photo. We can assume itвЂ™s his wife. The sweeping shot ends on Fred, sitting in a chair. HeвЂ™ staring bright-eyed at the sleeping woman. Lena opens her eyes and sees Fred. SheвЂ™s surprised.
ArenвЂ™t you sleeping, Daddy? Fred, trying to hide his tears, smiles sadly.
No, IвЂ™m looking at you. Lena notices her fatherвЂ™s tears.
But Daddy, you're...

(anticipates what she is going to say) DonвЂ™t worry. Old people cry all the time. And for no good reason. 6A. EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. DAWN. Early morning dew. The extensive hotel grounds, punctuate here and there by beautiful, centuries-old trees.  14. The chubby hooker and the petite, sixty-year-old woman we earlier at the reception desk appear, seen from behind. TheyвЂ™re probably mother and daughter. They walk hand in hand, sad and forgotten by the world. With a awkward, inelegant gesture, the girl adjusts her v short shorts, which have annoyingly worked their way in between her buttocks. Mick Boyle is sitting on a bench, looking over his work notes. He senses the presence of the two women and looks His eyes immediately grow melancholy when he sees the mot and daughter walking hand in hand. The sky beyond the high mountain peaks begins to brighten while the dew vanishes from the leaves of the garden's beautiful plants. 7. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. DAY Fred is on his stomach on a massage table. An eighteen-ye old girl, incredibly timid, slight, with delicate feature is giving Fred a massage. Lena looks out the window and sees an Asian man sitting a the far end of the garden.
That guy who levitates is out there.
IвЂ™ve been coming here for years. HeвЂ™s never levitated. So, where is it you decided to go?
Polynesia. For two weeks. Julian went overboard, as usual.
Good.
(smiling) You'll be glad to have the room all to yourself now. I was in your way.
Not at all. You kept me company. Mick is working and I get bored.
You wonвЂ™t be bored now. I arranged the full treatment for you. (MORE )
Massage and sauna every day, check- ups with the doctor... to help you get back in shape.
At my age, getting back in shape is merely a waste of time. IвЂ™m going to be even more bored now.

You're a victim of your own apathy, Daddy. Why donвЂ™t you go to Venice one of these days? You could bring flowers to Mummy. Fred doesnвЂ™t answer. The masseuse is very discreet, itвЂ™s as if she werenвЂ™t listening.
By the way, the French write to me every day. TheyвЂ™re really insisting that you write your memoirs. What should I do?
Let them insist. Lena stares at her naked father being massaged. His body worn with age. A wave of tenderness washes across her fac Sad now, she takes her leave.
Bye, Daddy, IвЂ™1ll call you when we get there.
Have fun. Lena wheels her carry-on out of the room.

(Swiss accent) Would you mind turning over on your back, please? Her voice is that of a young girl, which makes her even m charming. Fred turns over, though not without difficulty. masseuse starts rubbing his arms. His eyes are closed, but he opens one slightly, on the sl to look at the girlвЂ™s face.  16.

The day begins at this enormous compound, which is at onc hotel, a spa, a medical center, a sports complex, and a physical rehab facility. With established rhythms and wel defined schedules. In fact, antique bells ring throughout the hotel, so that guests will not be late for their appointments.
Nurses and masseuses, all in uniform, emerge from sterile changing rooms and head to their work stations.
Doctors don white coats.

The guests, most of them elderly, and all of them wearing identical hotel bathrobes, form orderly lines and head to their check-ups, or to the swimming pools, saunas, and massage rooms. The silent, serene, and sparsely attended activity of a w just set in motion.
The waiters, backlit, clear tables in the breakfast room.
An anorexic cook heads out behind the kitchen. Enjoying t first drag on his cigarette, he stares at the clear blue above the mountains.

Soporific, new age music pervades the room. In the darkness, relieved only by a sea of candles, Fred lying on an enormous straw crib, like an eighty-year-old Jesus. A little Thai man, about fifty, is placing burning black stones on FredвЂ™s body. Fred moans lightly in pain each one touches his skin. The masseur smiles, then says in halting English.
After pain come pleasure.
And then pain again.  17.
A nurse is drawing FredвЂ™s blood. A doctor, about sixty, comes in. He has a nice, kindly fa
HowвЂ™s it going, Mr. Ballinger?

ItвЂ™s going. I donвЂ™t know where, but itвЂ™s going. The doctor smiles. Then he stops and looks at FredвЂ™s fa puts his glasses on and examines Fred more attentively. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) My daughter says IвЂ™m apathetic. Is it that obvious?
(smiles) Would you like to have those sunspots removed? We could take them off with a laser.
No, why?
Because theyвЂ™re unsightly.
But they remind me of something fundamental.
What?

That my life is full of spots. The doctor smiles. Fred smiles. The nurse has finished drawing his blood. Fred looks out the window, which frame spotless mountain peak set against an unbelievably blue s Fred is serious now. 10. INT. MICK BOYLEвЂ™S SUITE. DAY The young screenwriters are in the middle of an argument. Mick, immersed in a sea of papers, listens but doesnвЂ™t intervene. Fred comes in, but no one pays any attention to him. They all too embroiled in their argument. So Fred listens impartially.  18. They're all talking at once, itвЂ™s impossible to make ou everything theyвЂ™re saying, but two of them, arguing fie are louder than the others. Naturally, itвЂ™s the boy and the girl who, according to are falling in love.
You've been watching too many movies, you idiot, youвЂ™ve forgotten what lifeвЂ™s about!

Movies are life! All you know how to do is criticize. If you only had some inspiration for once. He laughs and claps sarcastically. A shy screenwriter, sitting next to Mick, comments under breath on their argument.
Exactly!
Inspiration?! DidnвЂ™t they teach you at film school that inspiration doesnвЂ™t exist? InspirationвЂ™s a lie. ThereвЂ™s no such thing as inspiration, only fermentation.
Exactly!
Inspiration exists, alright, you just don't recognize it, because you have zero talent.
Exactly! Mick, hearing the contradictory remarks coming from the s screenwriter sitting next to him, addresses him harshly.
What the fuck are you doing? Agreeing with everyone?
Of course! I'm timid and insecure. My parents never gave me any encouragement. My brother's favorite sport was beating me up. My sister called me "the failure". (MORE )
I've never had a girlfriend, and I also have serious doubts about my sexual orientation. Mick stifles a laugh.
Stop it! YouвЂ™re not going to move me.
My aunt has polio. Mick laughs.
(furious) Don't you dare accuse me of having no talent ever again, you idiot.
NowвЂ™s not the time for fermentation, you untalented parasite.
ThatвЂ™s enough, youвЂ™re really getting on my nerves. We have to come up with an ending, and youвЂ™re wasting time talking philosophy and big ideas. Fred joins in.
But theyвЂ™re right, Mick. ItвЂ™s the big ideas that give rise to all the little ones. Only now do the others realize Fred is there.
Oh, Fred, youвЂ™re here. Listen, I still have a couple of hours to go here, and then I have to talk to the doctor. I'll find you after that.
Okay. Sad, and also a bit disappointed because no one even commented on his observation, Fred leaves the room, while Mick hounds his screenwriters.

Well? Come on, whoвЂ™s got an idea for the ending?  20. Another screenwriter, who hadnвЂ™t taken part in the argu speaks up. He has a long beard and tousled hair: the epit of a well-educated, ironic young man. As if having a visi he says dreamily.

So heвЂ™s on his deathbed, he can barely talk, and he whispers to his wife: вЂњDonвЂ™t cry, honey. You know IвЂ™ve always found women who weep frivolous and repulsive.вЂќ The two who had been fighting exchange a conspiratorial l and start to laugh. The timid, insecure screenwriter thinks for a moment and says with confidence.
Nice! Mick throws him a disgusted look, then says.
What a totally asinine idea. What else?

A deep torpor has settled over the hotel guests, as if th been anesthetized. The silence is numbing. In the early morning light, we watch a slow swarm of rich Russians dro onto chaise lounges to sunbathe, and a handsome black American family, immobile in the pool. Off to one corner, outdoor massages are available, in the shade of a beautiful canopy. Two teenage boys, in the swi of a hormonal tempest, are hanging around there, furtivel eyeing a beautiful woman who is getting an gentle, orient style massage. Few guests, all of them wealthy. We can make out a pair of parachutists in the distance, s against the crisp, imposing mountains. An elderly couple has dozed off in their electric wheelchairs. Their Asian caregivers are as discreet and invisible as m A fifty-year old son does gymnastics with his decrepit father.  21. At the far end of the garden, near the hedges that act as fence, the obese South American is leaning on a cane and signing autographs for a whole mix of people, all of whom seem bewitched by their hero. His companion at his side. eternal apprehension, she regulates how much time each pe gets with her husband. Someone takes out a cell and snaps photo on the sly. She is furious and orders a complete moratorium on photos of her husband. Fred Ballinger, wrapped in a white robe and lying on a ch lounge, sucks on a candy and watches, with resigned inter the autograph-signing ritual. One hand dangling off the chaise, he rubs the candy wrapper between his fingers, th irregular tempo creating a clear rhythm. Jimmy Tree is stretched out on a chaise lounge next to Fr He too is studying the South American, but seems more interested in his cane. ItвЂ™s of briarwood, made to look all twisted and full of knots. Jimmy looks around and something else catches his eye: a mother is rubbing suntan lotion on her thirteen-year-old daughter. The girl, so pale you can almost see through her, stares the ground, as if overcome by a pathological timidness. T for no apparent reason - she must have gotten nervous - s starts biting her fingernails, practically devouring them After a while, the mother apparently tells her to stop, because she gets all pissed off, screams at her mother, t gets up and storms off. Jimmy, an unlit cigarette dangling from his lips, studies like an entomologist. The South American, leaning on his cane and his wife, is coming across the garden. They skirt a deserted tennis co But his attention is drawn to a particular: a forgotten tennis ball lies in the middle of the court.

Fred and Mick stand next to each other at the counter of pharmacy. Fred waits impassively while Mick, glasses perched on the of his nose, checks to make sure that the pharmacist is getting everything right. The pharmacist places a whole range of drugs on the count in front of Mick, creating a veritable "mountain" of medicine.
That's everything.  22.
Good. Mick turns to Fred, and only now does he realize that his friend hasnвЂ™t asked for any medicine for himself. We ca the puzzlement in MickвЂ™s voice as he asks.

DonвЂ™t you need anything? So Fred, faking uncertainty, looks around the pharmacy an fixes his gaze on the first shelf he happens to see, whic contains a full selection of Bandaids. Fred grabs a random box of Bandaids and puts it on the counter in front of the pharmacist. Mick has observed Fred's actions closely. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) What do you need Bandaids for?

I donвЂ™t. IвЂ™m getting them out of solidarity with you. Mick turns back to his mountain of medicine and speaks in voice that is halfway between serious and humorous. Barel opening his mouth, he says to himself, but as if he were speaking to Fred.
Fuck you. A wry smile appears on Fred Ballinger's face.
Fred and Mick stroll through a meadow in a beautiful vall with an expanse of trees to the right, and the mountain village to the left. The two friends are chatting.
Why do you think we come here on holiday every year?
Because you always want to go back to the places that made you happy.
(smiles) ThatвЂ™s the screenwriter in you talking.  23.
I wish! Actually, itвЂ™s John Cheever.
Do you remember Gilda?
The film?

What do you mean, who is she? Miss Universe.
She looks completely different, unrecognizable.

She's been transformed, from watching all those robot movies. Fred doesnвЂ™t laugh. He canвЂ™t. He has to gaze dizzily Universe, whose beauty drains him. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) You know something, Fred? By dint of all our piss talk, we've forgotten that that organ is also made to fulfill other functions.
Take it easy with those illusions, Mick.
Illusions? You know they make these little pills now...
Yeah, but it distorts the reality of the situation.
And so? And what have I been doing my whole life making films?  88. Miss Universe languidly shifts her legs a few inches, jus enough to inflict further despair on our two old men.

Anyway, sheвЂ™s not interested, Mick, She's interested in a body that corresponds to hers. Sex is like music, it wants harmony. And rightly so. WeвЂ™re no longer in any condition to harmonize with anyone, Mick. They could cry at this point, and they might have, if an attendant hadnвЂ™t come into the sauna just then.
Excuse me, Mr. Boyle, thereвЂ™s someone here to see you.
(snorts) CanвЂ™t you see that weвЂ™re living the last great idyll of our lives? Well, who's the pain in the neck?
Brenda Morel.

Here she is, the genius, Brenda Morel. Who was once a dee mysterious femme fatale. Impeccable, sitting up straight small armchair. Over eighty years old. Numerous face lift delicate diamond choker sparkles among her wrinkles, whic are more obstinate than her plastic surgeon. A cascade of blond hair that make us wonder about her hairdresser. While she waits, she expertly runs her tongue over her en dental arch, making sure that her lipstick hasnвЂ™t stain perfect dentures. Mick enters, sparking an orgy of joy and affectation. But Brenda. She is serious. Aloof.
Brenda! What a fabulous, marvelous surprise!
Hi, Mick. They kiss each other on the cheek.
You look fabulous, Brenda. The very picture of radiance and sex appeal.  89.
You're getting mixed up with last millennium, Mick. Mick laughs theatrically.

What, you just couldnвЂ™t wait any longer? We just finished the latest version, you know. We were having trouble with the ending, but then yesterday, eureka! it came to us. So now that youвЂ™re here in the flesh, we can hand it to you. But didnвЂ™t you tell me you were going to be in Los Angeles? What are you doing in Europe? Brenda looks Mick in the eyes.
How long have we known each other, Mick?
Jesus, you're putting me on the spot! Let me count...
Fifty-three years. And how many films have we made together?
Nine, ten...
Eleven. And do you really think that after fifty-three years of friendship and eleven films together that now IвЂ™m going to start bullshitting you, of all people?
(bewildered) No, no I donвЂ™t... I wouldnвЂ™t deserve that.

Right, you donвЂ™t deserve it. You deserve me to call a spade a spade. Which is why I dragged my ass here from LA. To talk to you in person. Brenda's seriousness, her severity, makes Mick anxious.  90.

I see. Look, Brenda, if itвЂ™s about scene 21, where you're described as вЂњugly, feeble, a pale shadow of your former beauty,вЂќ well, please realize that thatвЂ™s just poetic license, but on set, naturally, we'll proceed in a totally different way. I want you to be extraordinary. You still preserve intact - you have to - that mystery, that allure that made you a diva in the first place.
DonвЂ™t go licking my ass, Mick, it just breaks my balls even more, especially given what I came here to tell you.
Why? What did you come to tell me?
IвЂ™m not doing the film, Mick.
What?

They offered me a TV series in New Mexico. A three year contract. An alcoholic grandmother who's had a serious stroke. A character with real balls. With the money IвЂ™1l be able to pay for JackвЂ™s drug rehab, my niece AngelicaвЂ™s film school tuition, pay off my idiotic husbandвЂ™s debts, and still have enough money left over for a house in Miami, which IвЂ™ve been wanting for fourteen years. ThatвЂ™s what I came to tell you. Mick objects, raising his voice.
But this is cinema, Brenda! ThatвЂ™s just television. TelevisionвЂ™s shit.
TelevisionвЂ™s the future, Mick. To tell you the truth, itвЂ™s also the present. So letвЂ™s be frank, Mick, because nobody speaks frankly in this fucking film world. (MORE )

You're going on eighty, and like most of your colleagues, you've gotten worse with age. The last three films you made were shit, Mick. IвЂ™m telling you, according to me and according to everybody, they were real shit! Mick Boyle is practically having a heart attack. He's shouting in a way he shouldn't, given his age and his hig blood pressure.

How dare you! How dare you! How dare you! So you want to be frank, do you? Fine, letвЂ™s be frank. Fifty- three years ago, if it werenвЂ™t for me, who was, is, and always will be a gentleman, you would still be crouching under some producerвЂ™s desk. I pulled you out of all those fat producersвЂ™ underpants and made you into an actress. Brenda is fuming, her eyes ablaze. She screams at him.

What a little shit you are! I was just fine in those producersвЂ™ underpants. And you know why? Because I wanted to be there. I donвЂ™t owe anybody anything. I did it all myself. I paid my way at the Actors Studio by cleaning toilets all over Brooklyn, my mother went into debt for me. And in Hollywood I walked through the front door, all by myself. Marilyn, Rita, Grace, they'd all shit in their pants when they saw me coming. ItвЂ™s all written down, right there in my autobiography, donвЂ™t tell me you haven't read it?

Unfortunately I have. Except you didnвЂ™t write it. And it was a piece of shit, your autobiography, just like this TV series youвЂ™re going to do, real shit. Brenda sighs, as if she needed air, but then, surprisingl she stops shouting. She calms down and starts speaking in quiet voice that makes her seem even more ruthless than w she was yelling.  92.

The real shit is this film of yours, Mick. I understand cinema, you know I do. YouвЂ™re the one who doesnвЂ™t understand it any more. Because youвЂ™re old, youвЂ™re tired, you donвЂ™t know how to see the world any more, all you know how to see is your own death, which is waiting right around the corner for you. Your careerвЂ™s over, Mick. IвЂ™m telling you flat out because I love you. No oneвЂ™s interested in your testament, as you call it, and you risk nullifying all the beautiful films you've already made. And that would be unforgivable. It was only because of me that they were even going to let you make it. So by pulling out, IвЂ™m saving your life. And your dignity. Mick is devastated. Completely drained. His words are cutting.

YouвЂ™re an ingrate. And ingrate and an idiot. Which is why you got ahead. But Brenda doesnвЂ™t hear his insults any more. Or maybe just doesnвЂ™t believe them. Regardless, she stretches ou diamond-encrusted hand and does something extraordinary: caresses MickвЂ™s cheek. Mick is on the verge of tears.
You're right, Mick, thatвЂ™s exactly right. Mick hisses between his teeth, his words full of hatred a revenge.
IвЂ™m going to make this film anyway. Even without you. Mick is crying. Brenda is still caressing his cheek.

Come on, Mick, life goes on. Even without all this cinema bullshit. Mick buries his face in his hands, destroyed. Brenda, like the last of the great movie stars, stands up smooths out her dress, which has gotten a few creases in grabs her thirty-thousand dollar purse, and with a regal, dignified gait, makes her exit.  93.

Spring must be coming to an end, because itвЂ™s the mime tonight. The whole nine yards: tails, whiteface, that per melancholy expression. In a corner, the man we saw earlier, all covered in mud, approaches Miss Universe.
Do you know you are the paragon of human beauty?

Do you know I was just thinking the same thing? The man walks away without uttering another word. The mime pretends to climb over an imaginary wall, but without success. Mick and Jimmy Tree, who has changed back in his own clot are watching the performance. TheyвЂ™re sitting next to e other, with Fred and Lena. Mick is catatonic. He looks but doesnвЂ™t see, staring of space with a monotonous expression.
Do you know how many actresses IвЂ™ve worked with in my carrier?
Lots... I guess.

(venting) More than fifty. I launched at least fifty actresses. And theyвЂ™ve always been grateful to me. I... IвЂ™m aa great womenвЂ™s director. Fred and Lena turn to look at Mick, but they canвЂ™t find right words or the right expression. Jimmy Tree stares into Mick's eyes and play acts.
вЂњThat way, Frank, that way youвЂ™ll never forget me.вЂќ Do you remember, Mr. Boyle?
Of course I remember. I remember everything I ever shot.

Mr. Boyle, youвЂ™re not a great womenвЂ™s director. YouвЂ™re a great director, period. The mime, exhausted from not being able to climb over the wall, crumbles to the ground and pretends to fall asleep. Fred Ballinger is looking at the mime. Lena is looking at her father. The hippy mountaineer is looking at Lena. There is a brief round of applause for the mime. The audience begins to disperse. The evening is over. Mic Fred, and Lena are heading off when the voice of the boy violinist calls out loudly, making them stop.

Mr. Ballinger. They turn around. The boy has ascended the stage and, vio in hand, plays the first, simple chords of Simple Song No All he can play are the first two chords, but heвЂ™s gott lot better. He plays them well and, even though he can on repeat them, their sweetness has the power to move anyone listens. Everyone is hypnotized by the child's simple playing. Jim Tree, Mark Kozelek and his friends, the mountaineer, Lena the South American and his wife, the German couple, all t elderly guests and their caretakers, the vulgar Russians, the black family, Frances and her mother, the waiters and doctor, the hotel manager and the cooks: itвЂ™s as if tim standing still, like in a fairy tale where every, stars a extras, join together. But only one person is truly moved by those simple violin notes. And itвЂ™s not Fred Ballinger, itвЂ™s Mick Boyle. tears in his eyes. And only Fred Ballinger, of all the people there, has not that Mick is moved. Fred looks at him impassively.

Lena, in a beautiful evening dress, stands at the foot of free-climbing wall, scrutinizing the height of the fake r face. The mountaineer must have followed her because heвЂ™s com behind her now. He approaches warily, intimidated, heвЂ™s almost reached her.  95. A bundle of nerves and embarrassment, he adjusts his shir surreptitiously straightens his hair, and then appears at side. Lena doesnвЂ™t even look at him, as if he didnвЂ™t He delivers an awkward opener.
Would you like to try to climb? Only at this point does Lena suddenly turn toward him. Sh pierces him with a look that could not be more sensual, a then addresses him in a serious, husky voice.

Do you know that I can make a man go wild in bed if I want? The mountaineer, as though it were the only natural thing do, looks up, goes white as milk, and falls to the ground a faint. A loud thud. Lena immediately abandons the role of the "femme fatale" becomes the apprehensive friend. She exclaims to herself.
Oh, fucking hell! She leans over the mountaineer lying on the floor. She sl his cheeks to revive him. SheвЂ™s scared.
Sir, sir! Wake up, fuck! Slowly the mountaineer comes to. He opens his eyes and se Lena's worried face a few inches from his. In a faint voice, the mountaineer says.
It takes a lot less for you to make aman go wild. Lena smiles, relieved.
The chubby hooker sits alone on a couch, looking sad. The lobby is deserted. Mick appears behind her and, without mincing his words, says.
Okay, I've made up my mind, I went to the ATM. The hooker turns to look at him.
And what would you want to do?  96.
(serious) Go for a walk.

Mick Boyle and the unattractive hooker stroll hand in han like new lovers, through the garden with its centuries-ol trees. ThatвЂ™s all they do. They donвЂ™t even look at each othe they walk slowly, hand in hand. While on a secluded bench, the two screenwriters suspecte falling in love are, in fact, in love. They kiss with tha intensity of first kisses. Endless, exhausting kisses. Al a sudden, the female screenwriter, without stopping kissi sees Mick and the young lady out of the corner of her eye

head_text.subj: EXT. MOUNTAIN VILLAGE. TRAIN STATION. DAY

text: The small train station in this mountain village. Mick Boyle and the five screenwriters, all of them blue, side by side on a bench on the platform, waiting for the train. The two lovers are holding hands. After a silence, Mick breaks the ice.

Come on, kids, whatвЂ™s with the long faces? Hitches, delays in screening, these things are constants in our line of work. Get used to it. IвЂ™ve already talked with the producer, we just need a little time to come up with another actress and then the shooting starts. ItвЂ™s just a matter of waiting a few more months.
What a bitch that Brenda Morel is.
Don't talk like that about Brenda Morel.
She goes where the wind blows.
Which is what we all do. And it's what you all will do, in order to survive in this jungle.  97.
It's not true that she came to Europe specially to meet you, Mick. I read that she's going to Cannes, some charity ball at the Film Festival. The other screenwriters throw him dirty looks.
Let's not get carried away with all this truth, now. Remember that fiction is our passion.
Your film-testament is worth a whole lot more than one more TV series, Mick.
My film-testament!? Let's not overrate things. Most men die not only without a testament, but without anyone even noticing.
Most men arenвЂ™t great artists like you.

It makes no difference. Men, artists, animals, plants - we're all just extras. The train has arrived. The doors open. The screenwriters their backpacks and start boarding the train. The last to climb aboard is the female screenwriter who hasnвЂ™t yet word. Mick stays on the platform, watching them. Just bef the door closes, she turns to Mick and, with a beautiful smile, says.
HeвЂ™s on his deathbed, and he dies. Only then does she say - and for the first time - "I love you, Michael." Mick smiles, moved.
Perfect! The door closes. The train pulls away and disappears arou bend. Mick, sad now, turns and leaves the station.  98.

Mick, alone and disappointed, shuffles along the same cou lane. HeвЂ™s all alone. ItвЂ™s a glorious day. Brilliant Blue sky. Crisp air. Chirping cicadas. A paradise. A woman's voice, as if it were coming from nowhere, calls him.

Mick. Mick turns to his left, where there is an immense uncultivated field, the grass three feet high. He looks, canвЂ™t see anyone. But then, a woman dressed like a 1950 stewardess materializes out of the grass. It was she who called him, and now she adds anxiously.

How am I supposed to say this line, Mick? I donвЂ™t get it. Mick doesnвЂ™t even have time to respond before another w she looks like a young Jean Seberg - pops up from the gra wearing a bikini. She sounds as if she is reciting a line from a film, in an ostentatious, snobby voice.
You may not know, James, that I never even step foot on a yacht that is less then 80 feet. Next a ditsy blond with abundant curves, 1960s style, app out of the grass, and starts reciting.
Come on, guys, where did you hide my lilac slippers? Enough already. Mick watches and smiles radiantly. Now a pious looking, middle-aged woman pops up and recite emotionally, on the verge of tears.

Oh Albert, if only you knew how much it has cost me to guard my virginity all these years, until today, until I met you! A magnificent countess in a nineteenth-century gown rises out of the grass.  99.
Prince, I am the owner of six castles and twenty carriages, but there is only one thing I can declare with certainty: life is so tiresome. And now a woman in the militant dress of 1968.

Sure, we all want a revolution, as long as it doesnвЂ™t tire us out too much. Mick looks happily at all his actresses, one by one, as t recite lines from his films. Another woman appears, about thirty-five, her back to us, long, flowing red hair and bare shoulders. She turns to t camera: a fabulous, authentic diva, dripping with allure. gives a sensual, nostalgic performance.

Okay, you win, I'll go to bed with you, but on one condition. That you donвЂ™t come. That way, Frank, that way you'll never forget me. One after another all of MickвЂ™s actresses appear, poppi out of the grass. Each one recites a line. The ones that been standing for a while just keep repeating the same li in a quieter voice. In short, that field becomes a garden of actresses - all types, all ages and eras, in all sorts of costumes (a soldier, a little old lady, a drag queen, a vamp, a singe gymnast, a ballerina with a tutu, etc.), all reciting the lines for Mick. The whining stewardess again.

How do you want it, Mick? Sincere, smug, wicked? And my walk? HowвЂ™s my character supposed to move? Mick is about to reply when yet another actress pops up a steals his attention. More than all the others, this one really shakes him up. He blurts out.

Mommy . All the other actresses fall silent, leaving the stage to this last actress.  100. ItвЂ™s Brenda Morel, in costume: a cheap, ugly dressing g decrepit, a pale shadow of her former beauty. She recites a neutral voice.

You were so cute when you were little, my boy. But whatвЂ™s so disgraceful is that youвЂ™re still cute. A cute, useless man. MickвЂ™s eyes are shining. The silence of the empty field ThereвЂ™s no one there. The vision is over. 64. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. DAY Fred and Mick are in FredвЂ™s bedroom. Fred in the armchair, Mick on the edge of the bed. Mick i looking out the window. Calm and disappointed. Fred eyes knowing what a difficult moment this is for his friend.
So you talked to the producer? Mick turns and looks at Fred.

IвЂ™ve been in this business too long not to know that without Brenda, this film is never going to be made. Silence. Mick reflects. Then Mick turns his gaze to FredвЂ™s night stand. He look the photograph of Fred and his wife hugging ten years earlier. Old, but happy. And beautiful. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Melanie is so beautiful in that picture.
You're right, she is beautiful.

You know, IвЂ™ve come to realize something, Fred. People are either beautiful or ugly. The ones in between are merely cute. Fred smiles bitterly. So does Mick. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) So... another vacation almost over. What will you do next, Fred?  101.
What am I supposed to do? IвЂ™1l go home, the usual routine.

Not me. I donвЂ™t do routine. You know what IвЂ™m going to do, Fred? IвЂ™m going to start on another film. You say that emotions are overrated, but that's bullshit. Emotions are all we have. Then Mick gets up, goes over to the glass door, opens it, steps onto the balcony, and, with remarkable simplicity, one foot on the wicker chair, the other on the railing, a lets himself fall from the fifth floor. Fred barely has time to stand up. Mick was so swift and s unpredictable, he didnвЂ™t give his friend time to do any to save him.

The Boeing sits on the runway. In the background, the mountains. In a LONG SHOT from the back of the plane, we watch the entire take off. The plane is full. We can see the back o everybodyвЂ™s necks from this angle. A stewardess strolls down the aisle. She turns politely t distinguished looking man.

Excuse me, sir, but youвЂ™1ll have to switch off your cell phone. The LONG SHOT continues. All of a sudden, from the other end of the plane - from business class, which is separated by a little curtain fr where we are - comes a hoarse, monstrous cry. It goes on on, a broken, bloodcurdling sound. All the passengers stretch their necks toward the little curtain, surprised. The stewardess dashes at full speed toward business class. The camera begins a long, slow tracking shot down the ais toward business class. As the dolly moves, the monstrous, deranged screams, whic seem to be those of a woman, echo throughout the cabin. M female cries, and the sound of a scuffle. The camera has arrived at the little curtain. It makes it way under it and enters business class.  102. The screams still persist, but theyвЂ™re fading now. By now all the passengers are on their feet, gawking. The camera elbows its way to the passageway in front of t cockpit and the exit door. We hear a jumble of confused voices, a muffled moan, and incomprehensible commotion. The camera has arrived at the center of the action: five stewardesses, done in by the physical strain, are literal immobilizing someone on the floor. One of them has a bloo lip. The camera goes to find out who it is, moaning and shakin feebly. ItвЂ™s Brenda Morel stretched out there on the floor of t plane, deranged, her torn dress riding up, revealing an o lady's flesh-colored slip, her make-up smudged, her face barely recognizable, disfigured by pain and tears, her wo fragmented and incomprehensible, frightening. She is bald. Her wig must have fallen off in the scuffle the stewardesses. A close-up of BrendaвЂ™s face. We now realize what she is saying. Exhausted but determined, she keeps mumbling to t stewardesses who are holding her down.
Let me off, you fucking bitches, let me off this damn plane immediately. The pilot comes out of the cockpit, breathless. He speaks Brenda.
Okay, lady, you win. I just got clearance from the control tower. We're going to let you off now.

Scattered across the hill, the usual cows with their bell ringing randomly. Fred is sitting on a rock facing them. He watches the animals, his face blank. Then he closes his eyes. The camera zooms in slowly. Fred moves his arm, as if directing an orchestra, but this tim nothing happens. The cowbells keep ringing in random, anarchic fashion.  103. Fred, his eyes still closed, makes a vexed gesture. He mo his arm more energetically this time, but still nothing. canвЂ™t seem to concentrate and compose in his mind. He is in need of music, but music no longer has need of h He opens his eyes. The cows are still there, in front of And in a loud voice he issues a command, a pretty stupid thing to say to a bunch of cows.

Be quiet. But the cows and their cowbells ignore him. Fred drops his head slightly. HeвЂ™s exhausted. His eyes with grief. Then, something surprising happens. Without any warning, parachutist lands silently in the middle of the cows. Fred looks at him. The parachute collapses on top of the covering him completely. He struggles to free himself, then looks around in surpri and realizes he has landed in the wrong place, right in t middle of a herd of cows. He looks at Fred and says calmly.

I donвЂ™t think this was where I was supposed to land. And, without waiting for a reply, he heads off across the hill. As Fred watches him, his eyes still wet with tears, he smiles. 67. INT. DOCTORвЂ™S OFFICE. DAY A magnificent bow window that looks out onto the mountain with an antique wooden birdcage. ItвЂ™s a gorgeous, round structure, with a magnificent blackbird inside. The bird is chirping a simple, perfect song. We are in the office of the sixty-year-old doctor. He is standing behind his desk, staring with dismay and concern Fred Ballinger, who is sitting on the other side of the d ecstatically contemplating the singing blackbird. The doctor beings in a tactful voice.  104.
Will you be going to Los Angeles for the funer-- Fred interrupts him.

Ssshhhh! The doctor falls silent. Fred, his face vacant, stands up and shuffles over to the window, to hear the birdвЂ™s song up close. The doctor too turns and looks at the bird, which suddenl and for no apparent reason - stops singing. Fred turns to the doctor and says, all in one go. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Birds are such artists! No, IвЂ™m not going to Los Angeles. IвЂ™m not going to Mick BoyleвЂ™s funeral. And I won't come back here on holiday either. Because itвЂ™s absolutely pointless to return to the places where you have been happy. Because you have to learn how to look everything else in the face. The doctor nods sadly. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Why exactly did you call me in here, doctor? What is it you wanted to tell me? The doctor sits on his desk. He picks up a medical file a opens it.
I have the results of all the check- ups youвЂ™ve been doing during your holiday.
And what do they say?
You're as healthy as a horse, Mr. Ballinger. Fred, hopeful almost, asks.
My prostate at least? The doctor is surprised.  105.

Your prostate? YouвЂ™ve never had a problem with your prostate. And if you havenвЂ™t had any problems so far, you're certainly not going to start having them now. Fred looks up at the doctor. Completely unexpectedly, he smiles. And says.

So IвЂ™ve grown old, but without understanding how I got here. The doctor gives him a sad smile. Fred turns and looks out the window. In the distance, he spots the young masseuse who is quickly crossing the hote garden in her white work smock. She moves quickly and gracefully, and Fred watches her with that same tinge of melancholy, while the doctor says to him.
So... do you know what awaits you outside of here?
No, doctor, what?
(smiles) Youth. The doctor reflects for a moment, growing sad.
Mick Boyle used to come by pretty often for a chat. Fred watches the masseuse disappear behind a row of trees jump into the pool. Then he asks the doctor.
By any chance, did he ever tell you anything about Gilda Black?
He never talked about anything else. Fred's ears perk up. HeвЂ™s consumed by curiosity. But he to hide it, in order to get the answers he is after.
Was she his girlfriend?  106.
вЂњGirlfriendвЂќ is way too much. The only thing that ever happened was one time, when they were kids, they held hands and walked together for a few yards in some park. Fred smiles to himself.
He used to call it "The moment I learned to ride a bike." DidnвЂ™t he ever tell you about it?
No. We only ever told each other the good things.

Venice is so beautiful. And mysterious. And unique. Especially at night, when the city is still, deserted, abandoned seeming, when even the most diehard tourists ha fallen into the arms of Morpheus. Canals, narrow streets, Saint MarkвЂ™s Square. Everything unmoving and statuesque. But then he appears. In the distance, small and vulnerabl with that tiny, old-man shuffle of his. And flowers, heвЂ carrying flowers. ItвЂ™s Fred Ballinger. HeвЂ™s walking a himself through this mysterious city. He crosses a small bridge. A motorboat glides underneath, not making a sound

A speedboat-taxi skirts the walls of the cemetery. Fred Ballinger sits onboard, serious and tired, staring into t void, the flowers in his lap. In the cemetery, he crosses the long avenues dotted with tombs. HeвЂ™s looking for someone. He approaches a few to but canвЂ™t remember. And besides, he doesnвЂ™t have much sense of direction. There, heвЂ™s finally found it. He stands in front of the of Igor Stravinsky. But he keeps holding the flowers firm in his hands.
Fred knows the way now. He shuffles along a narrow street that borders a canal. He turns a corner and stops. He loo up sadly and sees the sign for a private clinic.  107.

Fred, flowers in hand, stands in a room of the clinic. A sober, private room. And he looks. HeвЂ™s looking at a be the window where we see from behind an elderly woman, motionless, her hair loose, her forehead leaning against window. Fred plucks up his courage and arranges the flowers in a small plastic vase on the night stand. Then he pulls the photo he had in the hotel out of his pocket and places it next to the flowers. He sits down near her, his back to h He looks at the floor and, filled with an unusual shyness says.

I waited till it was visiting hours to come see you. Fred stares at the woman's back under the sheet. Fred is expressionless. There is no noise. Then, without emotion, without any intonation, Fred begin talk, in a simple, unhurried manner. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) They donвЂ™t know, Melanie. Children canвЂ™t know their parentsвЂ™ ordeals. Sure, they know certain details, the most striking elements, those they know. They know what they need to know in order to side with one or the other. They need to simplify things. And theyвЂ™re right. But they donвЂ™t know. They canвЂ™t know. They donвЂ™t know how I trembled the first time I saw you on that stage. And the orchestra laughing behind my back at my falling in love, at my unexpected fragility. They donвЂ™t know that you sold your motherвЂ™s jewelry so I could finish my second piece, when everyone was turning me down and saying I was a presumptuous, inelegant musician. They donвЂ™t know that you too - and you were right - thought at the time that I was a presumptuous, inelegant musician, and you cried nonstop, not because you had sold your motherвЂ™s jewels but because you had sold your mother. They donвЂ™t know how you loved me, and how I loved you. Only we know that. (MORE )
